unnormalised: For vegetables, you'll most frequently encounter weight-based measurements. Grams (g) and kilograms (kg) are the most common. You might ask for "250g of green chilies" or "1 kg of onions." The local vendor may often use the term "pao" which is approximately 250g (1/4 kg). Some old-school vendors still quote prices per "seer", an older unit equal to roughly 933g. While less common now, it's good to be aware of it, particularly in smaller towns. Keep in mind that the vendor may use a weighing scale of 20kg capacity but may try to pass of a 10% reduced weight if you aren't watchful. This is particularly true if you are buying at a price of Rs. 500 per kg.

unnormalised: When it comes to fruits, the same weight measurements generally apply. You might buy "500g of grapes" or "2 kg of mangoes". Depending on the fruit, you may also encounter prices quoted "per piece," especially for larger items like watermelons or pumpkins. For example, you might pay "Rs. 80 per watermelon," irrespective of its weight (though you can always try to negotiate based on size!). Buying fruits in dozens (12 nos) is also prevalent for smaller fruits like bananas.

unnormalised: For dry groceries, such as rice, lentils (dal), and flour (atta), kilograms (kg) are the standard. You'll typically buy these in larger quantities. You might purchase "5 kg of rice" or "10 kg of atta". Smaller quantities might be sold in grams (g), especially for spices. Remember that the price often decreases per unit when you buy in bulk. Many store owners may pass off a lower quality product if you buy in quantities of 50kg sacks, so please be aware of the brand before buying in bulk. The unit price is often marked as Rs. 45/kg and is usually inclusive of taxes.
